article.headline: Turner makes defensive stop on final possession

images.name: Loyola players 040307 inline
images.caption: Loyola Marymount players are ready to tackle the NCAA Tournament.

article.linkText: Loyola Marymount, wins WCC earns first NCAA bid
article.story:
SANTA CLARA, Calif. (AP) -- Loyola Marymount's defense keyed its
run to the top of the West Coast Conference. So it was only fitting
that the defense came up with the big play at the most important
time of the season.

Mary Turner bottled up Shannon Mathews on the final possession,
and Adrianne Slaughter shut down Gonzaga's inside game in a 61-58
win in the WCC championship Sunday, giving the Lions their first
NCAA tournament bid.

<photo1>

"Defense brought us here. Defense got us to this point,"
Loyola coach Julie Wilhoit said. "For us to end it on a big
defensive play sums up what kind of season it's been."

The Bulldogs trailed by three when they got the ball with 17.3
seconds to go. Needing a 3-pointer to tie, Gonzaga had to settle
for a wild layup attempt by Mathews when the Lions clamped down on
the outside shooters.

The ball went out of bounds off Loyola, giving Gonzaga one last
chance with 4.6 seconds to go. Mathews got the inbounds pass but
had nowhere to go as Turner tied her up and wouldn't allow her to
get a final shot off.

"When I get an assignment to shut someone down, I do whatever I
can to shut them down," Turner said. "I don't always do it, but
I'll come out with two broken legs if I have to."

Kate Murray scored 19 points to lead the Lions (24-5) to their
15th straight win since dropping the conference opener at Gonzaga
(18-11). Slaughter, the tournament MVP, scored 14 points, and
Rachael Ziemann added 10 for the Lions.

Slaughter again was a force inside, helping hold Gonzaga to 32 percent shooting. Ashley Burke, the leading shooter in the conference at 55 percent, was only 4-for-16.

"I give Slaughter the credit," Gonzaga coach Kelly Graves
said. "She's a load inside. She changes shots."

Slaughter said she overplayed Burke's right hand, forcing her
out of her comfort zone. Her teammates said there was also some
intimidation.

"I don't think Adrianne knows how scary she is," Murray said.
"If only she could play against herself."

Burke led Gonzaga with 18 points, including the last 11 of the
game for the Bulldogs. Mathews added 17, and Anne Bailey had 10.

After Burke hit two free throws to cut Loyola's lead to 58-55,
Murray fed Turner for a layup with about 35 seconds to go. Burke answered with a 3-pointer before Murray hit a free throw to make it 61-58 with 17.3 seconds left.

But the Bulldogs couldn't come through in the final seconds. The
Lions rushed out to center court to celebrate, capping a complete
turnaround of the program. Loyola Marymount went 3-24 with no
conference wins in 1997-98, Wilhoit's third year as coach.

The Lions came close to making the NCAA tournament three years
ago but lost in the conference title game to Saint Mary's. This
time they completed the task.

"I came to LMU nine years ago with the idea of turning this not
just into a competitive program in the West Coast Conference, but a
program that can compete on the national level every year,"
Wilhoit said.

Loyola Marymount scored the first seven points of the second
half to break a 30-30 tie and led the rest of the way. Murray
capped the spurt with a 3-pointer. After Gonzaga cut it to two
midway through the second half, Murray made four straight free
throws to make it 53-47.

Gonzaga snapped a 10-game losing streak in the WCC tournament
with a 66-64 overtime win in the semifinals against Pepperdine but
fell short in its bid to qualify for its first NCAA tournament.

"I was hoping, but it just didn't work out today," Burke said.
